channel.title: Bloomberg Economics
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 BLOOMBERG L.P. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED

item.title: New Zealand’s Willis Wants RBNZ to Add Summer Rate Decision
item.description: New Zealand Finance Minister Nicola Willis wants the central bank to increase the frequency of its rate decisions, ending its practice of a three-month summer break and bringing it in line with global peers.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Brockett

media:content.media:description: Nicola Willis, New Zealand's finance minister, during an interview in Sydney, Australia, on Friday, Feb. 23, 2024. Willis has cast doubt on her ability to return the budget to surplus by 2027, saying the weakening economy is likely to impact on tax revenue.

item.title: BOJ Likely to Ease Tapering Pace of Bond Buys, Ex-Official Says
item.description: The Bank of Japan is likely to slow the pace of tapering its government bond purchases next fiscal year at the board’s upcoming meeting, according to a former BOJ executive director in charge of monetary policy.
item.dc:creator: Toru Fujioka, Sumio Ito

media:content.media:description: The Bank of Japan headquarters in Tokyo.

item.title: ECB Rate Pause Until Autumn Makes Sense, Holzmann Tells ORF
item.description: The European Central Bank may be able to keep interest rates on hold over the summer, according to Governing Council member Robert Holzmann.
item.dc:creator: Zoe Schneeweiss

media:content.media:description: Robert Holzmann, governor of Austria's central bank, during a Bloomberg Television interview at the Kansas City Federal Reserve's Jackson Hole Economic Policy Symposium in Moran, Wyoming, US, on Friday, Aug. 23, 2024. Chair Jerome Powell said the time has come for the Federal Reserve to cut its key policy rate, affirming expectations that officials will begin lowering borrowing costs next month and making clear his intention to prevent further cooling in the labor market.

item.title: US May Exhaust Debt-Ceiling Measures in Mid-August, CBO Says
item.description: The US government could run out of enough funds to meet its financial obligations in a timely manner between mid-August and the end of September, the Congressional Budget Office said Monday.
item.dc:creator: Jarrell Dillard

media:content.media:description: The US Capitol in Washington, DC, US, on Monday, June 2, 2025. Significant changes are in store for President Donald Trump's signature $3.9 trillion tax-cut bill as the Senate begins closed-door talks this week on legislation that squeaked through the House by a single vote.

item.title: Fed Interest Payments Are Likely Here to Stay, JPMorgan Says
item.description: A proposal to eliminate the interest paid to banks that deposit cash at the Federal Reserve risks unleashing tremors across the industry, funding markets and US monetary policy, according to JPMorgan Chase & Co. strategists.
item.dc:creator: Alex Harris

media:content.media:description: The Marriner S. Eccles Federal Reserve building in Washington, D.C., US, on Wednesday, July 6, 2022. The Federal Reserve will unveil details of what policy makers debated last month that may shed light on how they view the near-term path for interest rates amid surging inflation and signs of a slowing economy.

item.title: IMF Wants Zimbabwe Gold-Backed ZiG to Become Sole Currency
item.description: The International Monetary Fund said it would like to see the ZiG “fully becoming a national currency” as it considers whether to place Zimbabwe on a staff-monitored program.
item.dc:creator: Ray Ndlovu

item.title: US, China Hold Trade Talks in London to Address Export Curbs
item.description: Trade talks between the US and China stretched on in London, with the US signaling a willingness to remove restrictions on some tech exports in exchange for assurances that China is easing limits on rare earth shipments.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Flatley, Catherine Lucey

item.title: Inflation Expectations Declined Across All Horizons, NY Fed Says
item.description: Consumers’ expectations for future price pressures improved across all horizons in May, and households’ pessimism about the labor market somewhat eased, according to monthly survey data released Monday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
item.dc:creator: Maria Eloisa Capurro

media:content.media:description: A shopper at a grocery store in New York.

item.title: Bank of Spain Cuts GDP Forecast as US Tariffs Cloud Outlook
item.description: The Bank of Spain lowered its 2025 growth forecast for the country, citing a high level of economic uncertainty due to US trade policies.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Basteiro

item.title: S. Africa Wins $1.5 Billion World Bank Infrastructure Loan
item.description: The World Bank has approved a $1.5 billion loan to support structural reforms aimed at boosting South Africa’s infrastructure.
item.dc:creator: Paul Burkhardt

media:content.media:description: A bulk water infrastructure project in KwaZulu-Natal, South Africa. Photographer: Leon Sadiki/Bloomberg

item.title: Mexico’s Inflation Tops Target Range, Testing Rate Cut Plans
item.description: Mexico’s annual inflation accelerated more than expected in May and breached the top of the target range, challenging expectations that the central bank will keep its half-point pace of interest rate cuts this month.
item.dc:creator: Maya Averbuch

item.title: India’s RBI to End Daily Fund Infusions Following Stance Shift
item.description: India’s central bank said it will stop daily fund injections into the financial system, days after the monetary authority shifted its policy stance and said the space for future easing was constrained.
item.dc:creator: Bhaskar Dutta

media:content.media:description: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) headquarters building in Mumbai, India, on Friday, April 5, 2024. India's central bank stuck to its hawkish policy tone Friday as warnings of a coming heat wave renewed fears of an inflation spike. Photographer: Dhiraj Singh/Bloomberg

item.title: London Infrastructure Set to Miss Out in Reeves Spending Plans
item.description: London is set to miss out on extra funding for new infrastructure projects in Chancellor of the Exchequer Rachel Reeves’ spending review on Wednesday, provoking an eleventh-hour row between the Treasury and the capital’s mayor, Sadiq Khan.
item.dc:creator: Ailbhe Rea

item.title: Trump’s Leverage Wobbles as China Trade Talks Get Started
item.description: One argument made for President Donald Trump’s tariffs is that they give him leverage over other countries. But what happens when signs emerge that his leverage is a diminishing asset?
item.dc:creator: Shawn Donnan

item.title: Here’s a New Way to Decode the BOE’s Policy Signaling
item.description: I’m Julian Harris, a UK economics editor in London. Today we’re looking at a new way to track the Bank of England’s policy signals. Send us feedback and tips to ecodaily@bloomberg.net. And if you aren’t yet signed up to receive this newsletter, you can do so here.
item.dc:creator: Julian Harris

item.title: Malaysia to Expand Services Tax From July 1 to Trim Deficit
item.description: Malaysia is expanding its sales and service tax to include the construction and financial services sectors effective July 1, according to the Finance Ministry.
item.dc:creator: Ram Anand, Anuradha Raghu, Anisah Shukry

media:content.media:description: A construction site in Kuala Lumpur. Photographer: Samsul Said/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump’s Tariffs Aimed at Reviving Manufacturing Are Doing the Opposite
item.description: President Donald Trump’s signature trade policy is threatening to backfire by upending other top priorities: the revival of US manufacturing and the American Rust Belt.
item.dc:creator: Mark Niquette, Miranda Davis, Brooke Sutherland

media:content.media:description: A sign in support of Donald Trump in front of a junkyard in downtown Springfield, OH,

item.title: Taiwan Exports to US Hit Record as Two Sides Talk Trade
item.description: Taiwan’s exports to the US jumped to a record, surging as companies fired off shipments before any tariffs hit — gains that come as the two sides try to hammer out a trade deal.
item.dc:creator: Yian Lee, Betty Hou

media:content.media:description: An image of a semiconductor wafer. Photographer: I-Hwa Cheng/Bloomberg

item.title: Europe Must Defend Rule of Law Standards, ECB’s Elderson Says
item.description: Europe can foster economic well-being and help increase the euro’s global role by adhering to and even strengthening rule of law standards, European Central Bank Executive Board member Frank Elderson said.
item.dc:creator: Mark Schroers, Alessandra Migliaccio

item.title: ECB Nearly or Already at the End of Easing Cycle, Kazimir Says
item.description: The European Central Bank is nearly, if not already, at the end of its cycle of interest-rate cuts, according to Governing Council member Peter Kazimir.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Hornak

media:content.media:description: The headquarters of the European Central Bank (ECB) beyond containers at a freight terminal in Frankfurt, Germany, on Thursday, March 6, 2025. The European Central Bank is about to lower interest rates for the sixth time since June, though a volatile economic backdrop is sowing divisions over where to take borrowing costs from here.

item.title: China Exports to US Fall Most Since 2020 Despite Trade Truce
item.description: Chinese exports rose less than expected last month as the worst drop in shipments to the US in more than five years counteracted strong demand from other markets.
item.dc:creator: James Mayger

item.title: Japan Should Use Asia Trade Bloc in US Talks, Party Chief Says
item.description: Japan should take a bigger role in a regional free trade agreement and use its expansion as a bargaining tool in tariff negotiations with the US, the leader of the country’s largest opposition party said on Monday.
item.dc:creator: Erica Yokoyama

item.title: S. Korea’s Lee, Japan’s Ishiba Vow to Boost Ties in First Call
item.description: South Korea’s President Lee Jae-myung and Japanese Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba held their first phone conversation and vowed to seek ways to deepen bilateral ties so both nations can respond together to future challenges.
item.dc:creator: Soo-Hyang Choi, Sakura Murakami

media:content.media:description: Photo by Kazuhiro NOGI/AFP/Getty Images Photographer: KAZUHIRO NOGI/AFP

item.title: China’s Rare Earth Exports Recover Ahead of US Trade Talks
item.description: Chinese exports of rare earths, a group of 17 minerals at the center of a trade dispute with Washington, rose 23% in May from the previous month, according to customs data on Monday.
item.dc:creator: Jason Rogers

item.title: BOE Risks Repeat of Brexit Pessimism as Growth Signals Diverge
item.description: Bank of England rate-setters risk underestimating the strength of the UK economy by placing too much faith in downbeat business surveys over official growth data.
item.dc:creator: Tom Rees

item.title: China Consumer Deflation Streak Persists as Price Wars Rage
item.description: China’s consumer deflation extended into a fourth month, as price wars intensified while a spending boost during two national holidays failed to offset the drag from weak domestic demand.
item.dc:creator: Lucille Liu, Jing Li

item.title: US, China to Resume Trade Talks With Focus on Rare Earths
item.description: The US and China are set to resume trade negotiations in London on Monday in a bid to further defuse tensions over rare-earth minerals and advanced technology following a phone call between leaders Donald Trump and Xi Jinping last week.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Lucey, Daniel Flatley

item.title: Japan Confirms GDP Contraction, Backing BOJ’s Cautious Stance
item.description: Japan’s economy contracted in the first quarter, a revised estimate confirmed Monday, weakness that supports the Bank of Japan’s cautious stance and keeps political pressure on Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba ahead of a key election.
item.dc:creator: Erica Yokoyama

item.title: Carbon Border Taxes Put South Africa Exports at Risk, Study Says
item.description: South Africa’s key export industries are becoming increasingly vulnerable as climate policies like cross-border carbon taxes take hold, according to a study by Net Zero Tracker.
item.dc:creator: Antony Sguazzin

media:content.media:description: Vapor rising from the chimneys of the Eskom Holdings SOC Ltd. Kusile coal-fired power plant in Mpumalanga, South Africa, on Friday, Jan. 17, 2025. A rare moment of investor goodwill for South Africa’s most indebted company is being tested by its inability to collect a staggering $5 billion in unpaid bills from cities and towns across the country.

item.title: US Inflation to Tick Higher as Tariffs Reach Consumers
item.description: US consumers probably saw slightly faster inflation in May, notably for merchandise, as companies gradually pass along higher import duties.
item.dc:creator: Vince Golle, Craig Stirling
